newsitem.title: NORWAY: Norway begins mediation in stalled wage talks.
newsitem.headline: Norway begins mediation in stalled wage talks.

text.p: Norwegian state-appointed mediator Reidar Webster began an effort on Tuesday to broker a compromise in deadlocked nationwide wage talks between workers and management.
"I will listen to the views of the parties today and then I will consider what to do," Webster told reporters before the mediation got underway.
Webster chaired a meeting with the delegations of the Trade Union Confederation (LO) and the Confederation of Trade and Industry (NHO).
He has until midnight (2200gmt) on Sunday to mediate a deal betweeen the parties, whose negotiations collapsed on March 19 after five days of talks.
LO, which is expected to call strikes if the mediation fails to produce agreement, broke off the talks with NHO because the latter refused to accept early retirement for some workers.

The parties also disagreed on whether some local groups were entitled to negotiate extra wage increases on a central basis in the talks, which are supplementary only to the two-year central wage talks which took place last year.
NHO says last year's nationwide talks meant real term wage growth of nearly three percent, helping to fuel inflation and hurting the competitiveness of Norwegian export industry.
LO chairman Yngve Haagensen, citing Norwegian law, was tightlipped about what strike action may be taken.
"When we are in a labour conflict the state mediator, in accordance with the law, asks us to refrain from taking action for two weeks," he said in response to a question.
Asked if he expected mediation to be tough, he said: "No worse than other wage talks".
A series of strikes hurting the offshore and manufacturing industries marred Norway's labour scene for a few months last year after state-led mediation failed to bring parties together in time.
